Expectation1: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation1: The site-wide evacuation alarm has just sounded, and you must stop everything and proceed to the muster point immediately.
Expectation2: Attend meetings and court sessions punctually
Situation2: They are expected at routine meetings that occur frequently
Story: The shrill wail of the evacuation alarm slices through the clatter of the construction site, and I drop my tools, heart pounding. Protocol is clear: leave everything, head to the muster point, no exceptions. My foreman’s voice echoes in my mind—teamwork, safety, no delays. But as I join the stream of workers, my phone buzzes in my pocket. It’s a reminder for the advocacy meeting I’m supposed to attend in twenty minutes, a meeting I can’t afford to miss. They count on me to be there, to speak up, to show up on time. I picture the faces around the table, waiting, expecting my punctuality and commitment. My boots crunch gravel as I walk, torn between the urgent demands of the site and the equally pressing responsibility to my advocacy work. The weight of both roles presses on my chest, each demanding my presence, each unforgiving of absence. I clench my fists, caught in the middle, knowing I can’t be in two places at once.
